bestBHT.bht: When someone exercises their spiritual gift in accordance with the prompting of the Spirit, it is edifying not only for themselves but also for the church. Even though the words may be unintelligible to others, the intensity of the prayer or praise can still be edifying to the individual. However, it is important that the person is able to interpret their own tongue in order to edify themselves and the church. Paul emphasizes that it is not about showmanship or self-glorification, but about the edification of the entire church community.

Henry Alford: The exercise of the gift in accordance with the prompting of the Spirit, may be regarded as an edification.
The intensity of the feeling of prayer or praise in which he utters the words is edifying to him, though the words themselves are unintelligible.
If he can interpret, he can edify not only himself but the church.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: understands the meaning of what the particular "tongue
expresses; but "the church," that is, the congregation,
Albert Barnes: The truths which are communicated to him by the Spirit...can be the means of strengthening his faith, and building him up in the hopes of the gospel."
His own holy affections might be excited by the truths which he would deliver, and the consciousness of possessing miraculous powers might excite his gratitude.
There might be danger that a man might be injured by this gift when exercised in this ostentatious manner.
John Calvin: He that speaketh in another tongue, edifieth himself."
Away, then, with that misdirected ambition, which gives occasion for the advantage of the people generally being hindered!"
Paul does, in effect, order away from the common society of believers those men of mere show, who look only to themselves.
Archibald T. Robertson: The church (εκκλησιαν). No article, literally, "a church" (local use). Not η εκκλησια.
John Gill: He that speaketh its an unknown tongue,.... Be it the Hebrew language, or any other; [...] knowing and understanding what he himself says.
his heart may be warmed, his affections raised, his devotion kept up, and he be in a very spiritual and comfortable frame
that which tends to the edification of more, even the whole church, must be preferable to that, which at most can only edify one, and that the speaker himself.
John Wesley: Edifieth himself — Only, on the most favourable supposition.

bhtAttempts.bht: When someone exercises their spiritual gift in accordance with the prompting of the Spirit, it is edifying not only for themselves but also for the church. Even though the words may be unintelligible to others, the intensity of the prayer or praise can still be edifying to the individual. However, it is important that the person is able to interpret their own tongue in order to edify themselves and the church. The purpose of spiritual gifts is to strengthen one's faith, build them up in the hopes of the gospel, and excite their holy affections. Paul emphasizes that it is not about showmanship or self-glorification, but about the edification of the entire church community.

When someone exercises their spiritual gift in accordance with the prompting of the Spirit, it is edifying not only for themselves but also for the church. Even though the words may be unintelligible to others, the intensity of the prayer or praise can still be edifying to the individual. However, it is important that the person is able to interpret their own tongue in order to edify themselves and the church. Paul emphasizes that it is not about showmanship or self-glorification, but about the edification of the entire church community.

When someone exercises their spiritual gift in accordance with the prompting of the Spirit, it is edifying for both themselves and the church. While the specific words may not be understood by others, the intensity of prayer or praise can still be spiritually uplifting. However, it is crucial for the individual to be able to interpret their own tongue in order for both themselves and the congregation to be edified. The focus should be on building up the whole church community, rather than seeking personal acclaim or attention.

When exercising their spiritual gift in accordance with the prompting of the Spirit, individuals can edify themselves and the church. Though the specific words may be unintelligible to others, the intensity of prayer or praise is still edifying. However, it is important for the individual to be able to interpret their own tongue to edify both themselves and the congregation. The emphasis is on building up the entire church community rather than seeking personal recognition. The goal is to strengthen one's faith and ignite holy affections for a spiritual and comforting experience.

The exercise of the gift, in accordance with the prompting of the Spirit, is edifying for both the individual and the church. Even if the words spoken in tongues are unintelligible, the intensity of prayer or praise can still edify the person. However, it is essential to be able to interpret one's own tongue to edify oneself and the congregation. This gift should not be used for show; rather, the focus should be on the edification of the entire church community.
